Title: How to prove that $k[x, xy, xy^2, \dotsc]$ is not noetherian?
Content: Consider the subring $R=k[x,xy,xy^2,\ldots]$ of $k[x,y]$ . I want to prove that $R$ is not noetherian. An ascending chain of ideals is the following: $$(x)\subset(x,xy)\subset(x,xy,xy^2)\subset\cdots$$ It is intuitively clearly to me that this is an ascending chain of ideals. But how do I prove it rigorously that $$xy^n \notin (x,xy,xy^2,\ldots,xy^{n-1})$$ or that this chain of ideals can never stabillize?
AcceptedAnswer: Preliminary remark Given a polynomial $f(x,y)\in k[x,y]$, write $[f]_{i,j }$ for its term $ax^iy^j$ in the monomial $x^iy^j$. Then for a finite sum $f=\sum_lf_l$ of polynomials we have $[f]_{i,j }=\sum [f_l]_{i,j}$ Proof that $xy^n \notin (x,xy,xy^2,\ldots,xy^{n-1})$ Suppose that $xy^n=\sum _{l=0}^{n-1}g_lxy^l$ with $g_l\in R$. From the preliminary remark we get $$  xy^n=[xy^n]_{1,n}=[\sum _{l=0}^{n-1}g_lxy^l]_{1,n}\stackrel{prel.rem.}{=} \sum _{l=0}^{n-1}[g_lxy^l]_{1,n}=\sum _{l=0}^{n-1}[g_l]_{0,n-l}xy^l$$  But all $[g_l]_{0,n-l}=0$ since $n-l\gt0$  and all non-constant terms of a polynomial in $R$ involve a positive power of $x$. Contradiction.
